Description

The SAM-II riboswitch is a RNA element found predominantly in Alphaproteobacteria that binds S-adenosyl methionine (SAM). Its structure and sequence appear to be unrelated to the SAM riboswitch found in Gram-positive bacteria. This SAM riboswitch is located upstream of the metA and metC genes in Agrobacterium tumefaciens, and other methionine and SAM biosynthesis genes in other alpha-proteobacteria. Like the other SAM riboswitch, it probably functions to turn off expression of these genes in response to elevated SAM levels. A significant variant of SAM-II riboswitches was found in Pelagibacter ubique and related marine bacteria and called SAM-V. Also, like many structured RNAs, SAM-II riboswitches can tolerate long loops between their stems.（from WiKi) SAM-V riboswitch is the fifth known riboswitch to bind S-adenosyl methionine (SAM). It was first discovered in the marine bacterium Candidatus Pelagibacter ubique and can also be found in marine metagenomes. SAM-V features a similar consensus sequence and secondary structure as the binding site of SAM-II riboswitch, but bioinformatics scans cluster the two aptamers independently. These similar binding pockets suggest that the two riboswitches have undergone convergent evolution. (from WiKi).


Gene association

Pathways for sulphate assimilation and biosynthesis of cysteine and methionine. SAM-II riboswitch (red bar) and SAM-V riboswitch (yellow bar) are involved in multiple gene regulation in the synthetic pathway[1，5].


Gene regulation

Potential mechanism of translation regulation by the SAM-II riboswitch[7].


Potential mechanism of translation regulation by the SAM-V riboswitch[12].


Structure and Ligand recognition

2D representation

Left: Consensus sequence and secondary structure model for the SAM-II riboswitch. Right: Secondary structure depictions of the SAM-I riboswitch according to PDB ID:2qwy.


Document



Left: Consensus sequence and secondary structure model for the SAM-V riboswitch. Right: Secondary structure depictions of the SAM-V riboswitch according to PDB ID:6fz0.


Document



3D visualisation

2.8-Å resolution crystal structure of an S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) riboswitch from thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis complexed with S-adenosylmethionine.SAM (shown in sticks) is labeled in red [3].
PDBe Molstar






2.50-Å resolution crystal structure of an S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) riboswitch from thermoanaerobacter tengcongensis complexed with S-adenosylmethionine.SAM (shown in sticks) is labeled in red [12].
PDBe Molstar






Binding pocket

Left: Surface representation of the binding pocket of the SAM-II riboswitch generated from PDB ID:2QWY. S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (shown in sticks) is labeled in red.Right: Hydrogen bonding between SAM and adjacent bases[3].


Left: Surface representation of the binding pocket of the SAM-V riboswitch generated from PDB ID:6FZ0. S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (shown in sticks) is labeled in red.Right: Hydrogen bonding between SAM and adjacent bases[12].


Ligand recognition

Chemical structures of various compounds used to probe the binding characteristics of the SAM-II riboswitch and SAM-V riboswitch[3,5].


References

[2] Molecular-recognition characteristics of SAM-binding riboswitches.

[3] Structure of the SAM-II riboswitch bound to S-adenosylmethionine.

Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 15, 177–182 (2008).

[4] Identification of candidate structured RNAs in the marine organism ‘Candidatus Pelagibacter Ubique’.

[11] A magnesium-induced triplex pre-organizes the SAM-II riboswitch.
